raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "Pseudomonas", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "The clinical scenario describes a child with cystic fibrosis (CF), which is caused by a gene defect on chromosome 7 affecting the CFTR transmembrane protein. CF patients have thick mucus in the respiratory tract, leading to recurrent respiratory infections. In childhood, Staphylococcus aureus is a common pathogen, but as patients age, Pseudomonas aeruginosa becomes the most common and problematic pathogen in adulthood, associated with chronic infection and decline in lung function.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
